ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course covers selected topics related to ancient civilizations of the Eurasian Steppes along with relevant comparative analysis.  Bill covers the material thoroughly and his teaching style makes the course quite enjoyable.
This course taught me how archaeology works and what sorts of questions archaeologists are interested in, specifically in a Central Eurasian context.
Learn about archaeology and the intersection of anthropology in the Eurasian steppe

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Honeychurch teaches the material in a way that fosters learning.  Bill assigns great weekly readings and other media formats.  His approach makes learning the material fun and easy.
Possibly one of the best and most chaotic classes at Yale. It doesnt feel like a class-more like a high level dinner party every time.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely!  The course material is fascinating, and Bill does a great job conveying his wealth of knowledge without being the least bit intimidating.

Definitely would recommend! I came into the course without any background in archaeology, and I found the course material sometimes challenging, sometimes approachable, but overall very engaging. There's a wide range of themes, topics, and especially teaching materials used in the course, from academic publications in archaeology and anthropology to films to novels. The amount of weekly readings can sometimes seem daunting, but it's absolutely doable.
